Dear Amanda Waidelich:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-
6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4157 Behavior Management
Section (2) At a minimum, the behavior management system shall include
Description all of the following:
(b) Positive intervention strategies to assist residents in
developing improved problem solving, self-management, and
social skills.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 4-28-23, an unknown bus aide grabbed Youth A by his
harness and was dragging/yanking him onto the bus, to the point
of choking him. Youth A sustained a red mark on his face for an
hour due to this. DART workers are not supposed to grab the
children by their harnesses. Bus surveillance footage from the day
in question was reviewed on 5-24-23. Before Youth A gets on to
the bus, he is laying on his back on the sidewalk refusing to get
on. One of the workers, a black male, grabs Youth A by his
harness and yanks him up onto his feet. It is unknown if Youth A
was injured from this but appears to be okay from the video.
Investigation Several attempts were made to contact and interview the
complainant. There was never a response to phone calls or
emails, however; the MDHHS worker was able to contact the
Complainant and a narrative is below in the Documents Reviewed
section of this report.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via phone, on 5/25/2023.
He reported being informed of the first allegation that the school
bus staff picked up Youth A by his harness and left marks around
his neck. He also reported Law Enforcement observed the video
recording and identified a DART staff help Youth A up by his
harness resulting in a second complaint being made. Youth A is
2

not able to be interviewed because of his limited verbal skills and
low functioning level.
Administrator 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility, on
5/25/2023. She reported being made aware of the incident and
reported the facility called in the complaint a month ago. At that
time, the allegations involved the school bus staff picking up Youth
A by his harness and swinging him around, leaving a mark on his
neck. She reported speaking to different staff to find out what had
happened. Administrator 1 has no issues with Staff 1, and he has
no disciplinary action in his HR file.
Administrator 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility, on
5/25/2023. He provided a tour of the location of the incident. He
reported observing the video and stated the facility does not have
a policy that staff cannot grab the harness of a youth. He also
reported it is understood verbally that staff should not grab the
harness of a youth and certainly not use the harness to direct or
guide the youth. Staff 1 informed him of what occurred and his
role in the situation. Administrator 2 reported Youth A has a
history of aggression and self-harming behaviors.
Youth A was observed at the facility on 5/25/2023. He was
engaged with the staff supervising him but was nonverbal. He was
highly active and the interactions with staff were appropriate.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone, on 5/26/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported being present
during the incident and shared how the bus staff grabbed Youth A
by the harness and swung him up into the bus. She also reported
the bus staff were rough with Youth A causing a red mark on his
neck. She believed Youth A dropped to the ground because he
was refusing to get on the bus. She was unable to recall how
Youth A got up from the ground and reported not seeing anything
inappropriate with the interaction between Staff 1 and Youth A.
Staff 2 reported staff cannot lift a youth up from the ground by the
harness and if she saw such action, she would report it to
administration. She views Youth A as being resistant when not
wanting to do something.
Staff 3 was interviewed via phone, on 5/26/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported being present
at the bus stop when the incident occurred. She reported Youth A
sat on the ground because he did not want to get on the bus. All
the staff helped him up and she had her hands under Youth A’s
arm and on his back during this process. She gave a similar report
3

to the actions by the bus driver and aid, reported they “yanked”
Youth A to get him on the bus and around the corner to a seat.
She never observed Staff 1 grab Youth A by the harness and
bring him to his feet and if she did observe staff taking this type of
action, she would report to her direct supervisor.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone, on 5/26/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported walking towards
the bus with Youth A before Youth A became upset and fell to the
ground. He also reported helping Youth A up by grabbing the
shoulder straps of his harness and Youth A’s feet never left the
ground during the incident of helping him up. He wanted to get
Youth A up as quickly as he could because Staff 1 feared Youth A
would incur an injury because he tends to injury himself if left on
the ground. The first time Youth A went to the ground he reached
out his hand for Staff 1 to help him up but did not do so the
second time, so Staff 1 grabbed his harness straps. Staff 1
believed he did nothing wrong because he was only trying to help
Youth A up but he believed policy states not to grab the harness.
He reported taking full responsibility for his actions and never had
any intent to harm or hurt Youth A. He also gave the same report
about the actions of the bus staff when they grabbed Youth A by
the harness and roughly placed him on the bus. Staff 1 reported
removing Youth A from the bus after witnessing the actions by the
bus staff because he feared for Youth A’s safety.
Staff 4 was interviewed via phone, on 6/1/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She observed the bus staff
grabbing Youth A by the harness and moving him in the bus,
however; she denied observing Staff 1 help Youth A up by
grabbing him by the straps on his harness. She believed staff are
not to grab the harness to move the youth and if she witnessed
this, she would inform the staff then administration. She reported
Youth A will generally get up from the ground with a few verbal
prompts after a period. She stated, “you need to offer your hand
and if he is willing, he will take your hands.”
Documents Reviewed:
Handle with Care Behavior Management System Manual for
Participants dated 2012. Nothing in this manual about helping a
youth up from the ground.
Developmental Adolescent Residential Treatment – Resident
Restraint, Emergency Restraint dated 3/16/23. This document
states the following. In the event an Emergency Physical
4

Intervention is necessary, it must be performed in a manner that is
safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity of the youth’s
behavior, chronological and developmental age, size, gender,
physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric condition, and
personal history, including any history of trauma, and must be
done in a manner consistent with the youth’s treatment plan. The
procedure for Crisis Prevention and Resolution and use of
Emergency Physical Intervention outlines that the DART Manager
and/or DART Clinician will immediately be notified when a youth is
having increased difficulty managing their emotions or experience
a challenging issue.
Developmental Adolescent Residential Treatment – Behavior
Management dated 2/18/21. This document outlines the
procedure for providing care for a youth who is not following the
expected behaviors. Staff are to encourage participation and the
Case Manager will meet with the youth to discuss rule violations
and concerns.
Kentwood Police Department Case Report 2023-00100269
dated 4/28/23. This report documents Youth A as the victim of
attempted Assault & Battery/simple assault. After reviewing the
video recording of the incident, Law Enforcement observed Youth
A walking towards the bus before sitting down on the lawn. Staff 1
helped Youth A back up by taking the hand Youth A held out. A
few seconds later, Youth A again sat down and appeared to be
refusing to stand up. The workers standing around Youth A
appear to be talking to him before Staff 1 is observed bending
down, grabbing the harness by the shoulder straps, and lifting
Youth A up. Youth A’s feet do not leave the ground and Youth A
walks to the bus with Staff 1 next to him. Staff 2 was interviewed
by Law Enforcement and gave the same accounting as she
reported during this investigation.
MDHHS workers interview with Complainant on 5/26/23. Face
to face contact was made with Complainant at the Kentwood
Police Department. The intake was called in to CI because when
she reviewed the bus video after getting a warrant for it, she
observed a DART employee doing the same thing the driver and
driver aide did, as the employee was seen grabbing Youth A by
his harness prior to getting on the bus, so she called it in. She
does not believe anything malicious occurred. She does not
believe the employees actions to be abuse or neglect but called it
in anyway. She does not believe the actions of the employee are
criminal in nature and stated Youth A was not injured as a result of
the incident. It was reported to her Youth A had a red mark on his
5

face for about an hour or so after, but there are no pictures of the
red mark.
Human Resources file for Staff 1 was reviewed. Staff 1 has
been employed at the facility for the past 6 years has no
documented disciplinary action in his HR file. He is current on his
trainings. His training included Trauma informed care, Handle with
Care refresher on 12/1/22, Staff/consumer interactions, Resident
supervision, and communication training.
Functional Behavior Assessment dated 3/2022 for Youth A.
This document outlines Youth A’s diagnosis and medication
regiment. His ability to conduct his ADLs are listed. A behavior
support plan is part of this document and lists the target behaviors
for Youth A which are listed as skin picking, physical aggression,
disrobing, and property destruction. Several preventative
strategies are listed which include keeping him busy and engaged,
redirecting, providing choices, and encouraging him to play with
sensory stimulating toys. If Youth A is engaging in minor disruptive
behavior, staff are to redirect him “to a task which is incompatible
with the behavior we want him to stop doing”. Reinforcement and
reactive strategies are listed and when Youth A engages in
disruptive behavior (falling to floor, crying, yelling, physical
aggression) after a request is made of him, staff should engage in
the following behaviors.
• Maintain a neutral facial expression and tone of voice. Wait
until disruptive behavior has ended, then repeat the
request.
• If he requires assistance in completing the request, prompt
him to functionally request help.
• Repeat the steps as needed.
• Provide praise for any positive behavior.
Youth A individual safety & calming plan dated 10/24/22. This
document outlines Youth A’s triggers, counterproductive strategies
not to use (force him to complete a task), precursors to aggression
& self-injurious behavior, calming strategies & coping skills, pro-
active strategies, crisis intervention strategies, elopement
prevention, and emergency safety/last resort. This document is
signed by his clinical manager.
Incident/accident report dated 4/28/2023. This document was
the original incident in which the bus staff were identified as
grabbing and yanking Youth A by his harness. Witnesses to this
action were identified as Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, and Staff 4. There
is no mention of Staff 1 picking Youth A by his harness.
6

Updated Service Plan for Youth A dated 4/7/23 by Foster Care
Worker. This document indicates Youth A is on 1:1 supervision
because of the presenting problems. There is no time frame for a
reduction in this supervision and because of his limitations his stay
at the facility has no ending date currently.
Treatment Plan Periodic Review for Youth A dated 4/10/23.
This document outlines Youth A continues to require maximal
prompts to engage in therapist directed activities. He requires
maximal prompts to wait with eating and struggles to chew and
swallow before taking another bite of food. Youth A is not meeting
his goal for disrobing, physical aggression, and skin picking. In
summary, Youth A continues to exhibit behaviors that require
constant supervision and support. He has made some
improvement in his engagement with the treatment team but will
return to behaviors that require constant redirection. Youth
received individual therapy sessions and engaged in weekly
therapy during this period.
Video Review
The camera angle is from the back of the bus looking forward and
to the right. Within this view, Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, and Youth A
can be observed. Staff 1 and Youth A are walking towards the bus
when Youth A falls to the ground. Staff 1 appears to be talking to
Youth A and Youth A puts out his hand which Staff 1 grabs and
helps him to his feet. A few moments later Youth A again falls to
the ground. Staff 1 and other staff appear to be talking to Youth A
before Staff 1 grabs Youth A’s harness by the shoulder straps and
helps him to his feet. There is no jerking or any other inappropriate
action in this move by Staff 1. Youth A’s feet never leave the
ground. Youth A and Staff 1 then walk to the bus door.
Analysis Based upon interviews, written documentation, and video
recordings evidence supports Staff 1 did not follow Youth A’s
safety & calming plan. When Staff 1 brought Youth A to his feet by
holding his harness straps, he was forcing Youth A to complete a
task when the plan is not to force Youth A to complete a task.
Staff 1’s actions also did not allow Youth A to develop improved
problem-solving skills.
TECHNICAL ASSITANCE:
It was recommended the facility address the issue of staff not
acknowledging the action even though they were standing next to
Staff 1 and Youth A. It was recommended to the facility they
address the use of a harness in their policies and procedures.
Conclusion Violation Established
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
